moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Bf4 d6 3. Nf3 Nbd7 4. Nbd2: White doesn't like to exchange his dsb, but I do like the open column.
moves.5. Bg3 Nxg3 6. hxg3 e5: The counterside is black is able to play e5.
moves.7. e4: If he takes, I retake and nothing happens. So I get presence in the center and open the way for my lsb.
moves.7... Be7: I don't like this move from my opponent's part. The grip on g4 only means to exchange his dsb for my N, who'll be replaced.
moves.8. Bc4 c6 9. Nh4: !? The idea is threaten Nf5, pressing d6 / NxB / Nxg2+. His move is g6, but he likes his castling fortress, because on the Qside is far from become free for castling.
moves.10. Bb3 a5 11. a4 b4: NO problem. His own pawns are my defence. But now I "saw" a nice hole on c4, and I ran to occupy it without thinking.
moves.12. Nc4 Nf6 13. Qf3: I played this thinking that after...
moves.13... Bg4 14. Qd3: ...now I have f3, etc, kicking the B and gaining tempoes.
moves.14... exd4: Now, this is classic: Qxd4, c5, Qmoves... boring and... not good for me.
moves.15. f3 Be6 16. Nf5: It seems almost forced black exchanges one of his Bs
moves.16... O-O: Now it is very juicy. I smell blood.
moves.17. Qxd4: ?? I had to hold on. I "saw" NxB+, forcing the Q to take, following Qxd6, but I failed to see...
moves.17... d5: The situation suddenly changes. Ne5 was probably the move.
moves.18. Nxe7+ Qxe7 19. exd5 Bxd5+: Ups, check! I was so fool... well I can still use the tempo given by kiking the BQ.
moves.20. Kd2 Bxc4: It leaves me as a tangled tangler. I've fell into my own tactic-style... would I survive?
moves.21. Qxc4 Rad8+ 22. Kc1 Qe3+ 23. Kb1 c5: Qh4, g4-g5. No time for it.
moves.24. Ka2: R's active again. If Rd4, Qxc5.
moves.24... Qf2: Threatening my pawns. My opp is missing to use his N (Nd5, Ne3...) but if he moves it, he allows Qg4.
moves.25. Rh2: Doubling the R on h whorts pawns.
moves.25... Qxg3 26. Rah1: I still threat c5, but my intention is not to take it lightly.
moves.26... h6: Now: Rxh6, and Nf6 gets undefended.
moves.27. Qxc5: I have to use my Q.
moves.27... Rda8 28. Qc6: The idea is Rxh6, and if I manage to QxNf6...
moves.28... Qe5: Preventing it. But I have another (very bad) plan. I didn't noticed (blitz, seconds...) that b8 was defended by the Q, and I hoped to play my Q on 7th, trheatening a R, and then Bxf7+ (where RxB, QxR+).
moves.29. Qb7 Rab8: Now I played the combination, without seeing Rg8 is defended. What a shame!
moves.30. Bxf7+ Kh7: !? Rxa6 works? I don't think so. It's tempting. Otherwise, the initiative turns to him. It is deadly?
moves.31. Qa7 b3+ 32. cxb3: If I take with the B, it will become an easy target, like b2.
moves.33. Bc4: The theater is full, and the curtain up. I've spotted the combination in a second, no time to check it.
moves.33... Rba8: Thanks! Here it goes, and I am sure he doesn't expect it.
moves.34... Kh8 35. Rh2xh6+: I'm pretty sure he didn't expect it. For a good player, it is easy to see. The point is Qh7# is threatened.
moves.35... Nxh6 36. Rxh6+ Kg8 37. Bc4+: The magic of tactics: All my major forces are threatened, but I'll give mate. A nice position for "tactic trainer" excercise.
